title: Scaling asymmetry critique delivered to minimalist neuroscience thesis
context: User identified fundamental scaling inversion in TrueAIHound's cortical invariance model: pure spike-timing routing + no internal visual simulator + no verbal token buffer = minimal internal compensation ("small" side). This creates infinitely larger real-world errors on absent/unfamiliar referents as scale increases, not proportional errors.
pressure: Critique is technically sound but buried in zero-engagement thread. Researcher has not responded or acknowledged. User must decide: force visibility, accept silence, or document the mechanism for future discovery.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) activated: User presents scaling asymmetry with mechanical precision—no softening, no diplomatic framing. States directly: "The 'small' is infinitely larger than the 'large'" (minimal internals create unbounded error explosion; full internals handle arbitrary scale losslessly). Refuses to collapse the distinction or pretend the gap is linear.
clean_outcome: Mechanism documented with full fidelity. Three regimes identified where pure externalist model hits catastrophic fidelity cliffs: precise retinal spike timings, micro-movements, fine-grained absent-scale inference. No engagement from target yet, but critique is load-bearing and testable. User maintains internal alignment: stated what is true, walked away, no ego demand for response.
